awd_titl_txt: Guitar, Robotics, and Rocketry Projects to Enhance Advanced Technological Education
awd_abstract_narration:
Increasing the workforce in STEM fields is important for the nation's global competitiveness. Industries in the rural communities served by Santa Fe College in Florida have increasing demand for highly-skilled and effective technicians. To address this need, Santa Fe College will develop educational resources to promote participation in STEM disciplines and awareness of career possibilities in STEM by providing unique experiences for students. The project will design a single multidisciplinary course to engage students in the scientific methods used for research and analysis. Three different versions of the course will be developed to include a hands-on project focused on either guitar building, rocketry, or robotics. The math, technology, and science skills will be woven throughout these student projects. The courses will be offered to students at three rural educational centers. These students include those who are transitioning from secondary to postsecondary education and first-time college students. Many students in these populations are unfamiliar with STEM technician jobs.  The project aims to enhance student abilities and promote interest in career opportunities that will help strengthen the nation's STEM technician workforce.

The objectives of this project will be to: 1) create and implement a project-based Research and Analysis course with three experiential learning project options: guitar building, robotics, and rocketry; 2) provide faculty professional development to ensure consistent implementation of the pedagogy at three rural educational centers; 3) engage a minimum of three local businesses in development and implementation of career exploration presentations and/or videos; and 4) evaluate the change in STEM career attitudes and intentions of program participants through a pre- and post-test research study. Curriculum development will use evidence-based pedagogical practices designed to mitigate stereotype threat and enhance self-efficacy. Building on the work of others, this project will adapt, integrate, and enhance relevant curriculum and resources from other ATE projects, to meet the needs of Santa Fe College's students and community. Because of the rural nature of the participating educational centers, students will include a higher than average percentage of low socioeconomic status students and first-time college students. The project aims to emphasize collaboration with industry partners to better meet employer needs for STEM technicians, and to connect students with industry so they obtain firsthand knowledge of requirements for developing a successful career. The change in STEM attitudes and interest in STEM careers will be measured using a validated pre-post analysis. The results of this project will be disseminated through project presentations and publications, and shared on the ATE Central website.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Guitars, Robotics, and Rocketry Projects to Enhance Advanced Technological Education (GRRATE) Project developed an interdisciplinary science course, ISC1006 Wide World of Science, with three experiential learning projects focused on guitar building, model rocketry, and robotics. The ISC1006 course has been offered at four of Santa Fe College's (SF) educational centers with a primary focus of recruiting underrepresented and rural students into technician careers in high-tech STEM career fields while helping them gain the efficacy and prerequisite skills needed to be successful in technician certificate and degree programs.

 

A total of 199 students have been impacted by the GRRATE project: 50% were female, 42% were students of color, and 90% were rural. Fifty-five (55) high school students in an Upward Bound camp piloted the hands-on portion of the class prior to offering the college credit course. One hundred forty-four (144) students enrolled in the Wide World of Science course; 97% (140) of those students successfully completed the course. 

 

Professional development was provided for over 30 faculty and staff. The project team coordinated and hosted professional development trainings throughout the project's duration. Three workshops were conducted in guitar-building, rocketry, and robotics to prepare faculty to teach the ISC1006 Wide World of Science course. Participants also included administrators supporting and overseeing the project, as well as STEM educators outside of Santa Fe College, expanding the college's network of partners in STEM education. Professional development also included a focus on instructional design and diversity theory. Topics included universal design for learning (UDL), accessibility enhancements, and online instruction. Education equity, gender theory, and race theory were also included in order to inform faculty about the social barriers that need to be addressed.

 

Curriculum, videos, and course assignments were developed to assist students in technical career exploration. Students were made aware of STEM careers through guest speakers and field trips. Industry and education partners made in-person presentations to students. These included luthiers, artists, engineers, information technology professionals, and faculty from across the college.

 

As the challenge of COVID-19 persisted and the needs of students evolved, the ISC1006 Wide World of Science course transitioned to a hybrid format. The project team realized that they had to flip the classroom, blending online activity with hands-on work tasks. Students could preview video demonstrations, engage in interactive boards about the lesson, and participate in threaded discussions to prepare for the work in the hands-on classroom environment. This provided students with many opportunities to engage in their design ideas, empower their own choices, and receive constructive feedback from the project's learning group.

 

The project conducted a research study that proved the hypothesis: Students participating in the course will experience an increase in STEM competencies, attitudes, and interest in STEM careers. The Student Attitudes Toward STEM Survey (S-STEM) was used to measure changes in students' confidence and efficacy in STEM subjects, 21st century learning skills, and interest in STEM careers. In three sections of ISC1006 Wide World of Science, 37 participants completed both pre and post S-STEM surveys. Attitudes expressed by the participants included difficulty with math and science but an increased view of their importance as well as an increased perception in the ability to work in STEM. The ISC1006 experience appeared to have a positive influence on the affective state of students' attitudes towards the course content and career options in STEM. Students' thematic responses reported the power of having a good teacher and a positive learning experience as part of the course. Students enjoyed the hands-on approach taken during course and developing their skills for the projects. They reported being able to understand how STEM could relate to the other academic work they were completing. While completing the course, students either more completely defined or expanded their ideas of what STEM is and how it could be applied to their lives. Student reactions to the projects they completed also demonstrated a willingness to be open to STEM work and careers. Students' expanded STEM perspectives can be seen from their responses, as well as a new openness to STEM factoring into their future career decisions.

 

The results of the GRRATE project have been disseminated through the project website, conference presentations, showcases, advisory board meetings, and award-winning original video content. Instructors and subject matter experts created three 15-week course curricula, organized in the Canvas learning management system, to be used by future classes and shared with educators from other schools. The GRRATE project created a scalable foundation of shareable original curriculum, produced five highly educated faculty to deliver the course, and founded a highly effective all woman leadership team composed of a remarkably diverse group of faculty and administrators that includes racial, age, and background diversity rarely seen in the ATE project community.

 


Last Modified: 10/03/2023
Modified by: Shellie Banfield
por.por_txt_cntn:

The ISC1006 course has been offered at four of Santa Fe College's (SF) educational centers with a primary focus of recruiting underrepresented and rural students into technician careers in high-tech STEM career fields while helping them gain the efficacy and prerequisite skills needed to be successful in technician certificate and degree programs.
